result.title: Objective
result.description: Increase the resilience and adaptive capacity of Samoa's forest areas and communities reliant on Samoa's forestry resources.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Ha of increase in forest coverage in upland forestry areas composed by climate resilient native species

baseline.comment:
To be defined through the update of SamFRIS during 1st year of the project
This was define using existing SAMFRIS data and updated to 2004 as baseline. Year 2: Baseline level was measured on existing SamFRIS data as follows: 1. Northern Upolu upland healthy forests (montane and ridge rainforests): 4,724 ha 2. Lake Lanotoâ€™o upland healthy forests (montane rainforests): 342 ha 3. Mauga o Salafai upland healthy forests (Cloud and Montane rainforests): 5,532 ha

target.comment: Target levels set in year 2 are assessed based on current disturbed and unhealthy upland forests, and estimated rehabilitation capacity of the project over the next two years. 1. Northern Upolu upland forestry area: at least 28 ha increase (rehabilitation of disturbed forests). Total target of healthy forest area: at least 4,752 ha 2. Lake Lanotoâ€™o upland forestry area: at least 12 ha increase (rehabilitation of disturbed forests): Total target of healthy forest area: at least 352 ha. 3. Mauga o Salafai upland forestry area: at least 10 ha increase (rehabilitation of disturbed forests). Total target of healthy forest area: at least 5,542 ha.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Ha of increase in forest coverage in lowland forestry areas composed by climate resilient and high-value species

baseline.comment: To be defined through the update of SamFRIS during 1st year of the project This was define using existing SAMFRIS data and updated to 2004 as baseline. Year 2: Baseline level was measured on existing SamFRIS data as follows: 1. Northern Upolu lowland healthy forests: 922 ha 2. Mauga o Salafai lowland healthy forests: 0 ha

target.comment: Target levels set in year 2 are assessed based on current disturbed and unhealthy lowland forests, and estimated rehabilitation capacity of the project over the next two years. Year 2: Baseline level was measured on existing SamFRIS data as follows: 1. Northern Upolu lowland disturbed forests ecosystems: 28 ha. Total target for resilient lowland forests: 950 ha 2. Mauga o Salafai lowland disturbed forests ecosystems: 10 ha. Total target for resilient lowland forests: 10 ha.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of farmer organizations/networks and farmers in Samoa who have increased their adaptive capacity through a) implementing forestry and agroforestry adaptive measures b) receiving climate information services on a regular basis and c) receiving information on good adaptive practices and participating in knowledge sharing activities

baseline.comment: Rural communities in Samoa lack the capacity to integrate climate-resilient management techniques into their forestry use and agroforestry management practices

target.comment: By the end of the project: a) 4 farmers\' organizations/networks (METI, WIDBI, SFA, FD Community Forest Programme) and at least 1000 farmers in the 26 pilot villages are implementing adaptive practices; b) at least 2000 farmers are receiving climate and forestry information services on a regular basis; c) at least 3000 farmers receiving information on good adaptive practices and participating in knowledge sharing activities

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Climate risk and resilience integrated into lowland agroforestry and upland native forestry policies, strategies and management techniques

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: National Policy on Sustainable Forest Management and Forestry Management Bill revised to integrate CC risks, and new National Forest Plan and Forest Fire Prevention Strategy developed with adaptation options incorporated

baseline.comment: Forestry policy frameworks do not integrate climate risks

target.comment: By the end of year 2 the NPSFM is revised and based on that a new National Forestry Sector Plan and Forest Fire Prevention Strategy developed. By the end of year 3 the Forest Management Act revised to reflect the policy changes.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Existence of forestry and climate information tools

baseline.comment: SAMFRIS is outdated and does not includes only limited climate info. CLEWS is not tailored to the forestry sector

target.comment: By the end of year 2, SamFRIS is updated with climate information integrated from forestry tailored CLEWS

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of government officers and farmers regularly receiving climate early warning and forestry information services

baseline.comment: Officers and end users does not receive tailored climate and forestry information supporting forestry and agroforestry practices

target.comment: By the end of year 3 at least 50 officers (including FD, MDEC, MAF, MET Division and their extension officers and local representatives) and at least 2000 farmers (at pilot villages and through farmers\' organizations) receiving climate early warning and forestry information services

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Climate resilient agro-forestry and forestry techniques are demonstrated in lowland and upland areas

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Existence of climate-sensitive management plans in the NPs and CBCA

baseline.comment: Currently there are no management plans for the Lake Lanotoo and Mauga o Salafai NPs.

target.comment: By the end of year 2 climate-sensitive management plans are prepared for the Lake Lanotoo, Mauga o Salafai NPs, and a CBCA established with similar management plan for the upland areas of the 14 villages between Laulii-Falevao

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: N. of district level committees established and functioning

baseline.comment: There was a past attempt to establish a CBCA only at Laulii village, only exist in paper and dysfunctional. Currently the only protected area with a committee involving adjacent villages is at the O le Pupu Pue NP in Samoa

target.comment: By the end of year 1, 3 district-level committees established at village adjacent to Lake Lanotoo and Mauga o Salafai NPs and at community demo area between Laulii-Falevao villages, involving village leaders, gov. officials and NGO reps.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of farmers participating in climate-resilient landuse and forestry planning processes, and n. of farmers implementing adaptive forestry and agroforestry practices

baseline.comment: Currently the only protected area with a committee involving adjacent villages is at the O le Pupu Pue NP in Samoa

target.comment: By end of the year 2 at least 1500 farmers participating in climate-resilient land-use and forestry planning processes, and by the end of the project at least 1000 farmers are implementing adaptive agroforestry and forestry practices in the participating 26 pilot villages

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Project knowledge and lessons learned are captured, analyzed and disseminated

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of knowledge management products generated and disseminated

baseline.comment: The analysis and dissemination of adaptation lessons learnt is very fragmented and limited to a number of incipient projects

target.comment: Starting from year 2 of the project, at least 5 lessons learned and best practices consolidated every year in form of case studies, experience notes, brochures, photo stories or audio-visual materials and disseminated directly to communities and through appropriate media

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of farmers receiving tailored knowledge management products on good adaptive practices and participating in knowledge sharing activities.

target.comment: By the end of the project at least 1500 farmers in the pilot villages, and 1500 farmers involved in farmers\' organizations/networks receive knowledge products and participate in knowledge sharing activities.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of national, regional or international events and platforms, where project experience is presented

target.comment: Project experience and KM materials are presented in at least 2 national workshops, 2 regional events, and in at least 2 international web-based platforms

result.title: Objective
result.description: To strengthen local capacities, incentives and actions for integrated landscape management to reduce land degradation and greenhouse gas emissions and to promote conservation whilst enhancing sustainable local livelihoods

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Area under increased vegetative cover

baseline.comment: 0 ha

target.comment:
24,430 ha
[This figure is based on 18,930 ha of changes in current agricultural land-use practices and at least 5,000 hectares of degraded lands restored through community activities and further 500 hectares will be forests]

actual.comment: 0 ha

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Area under forest cover (no net loss due to landuse conversion) under effective management

actual.comment: To be reported on at MTR

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Increase of agriculture income and consumption per household as a consequence of increased productivity of land

baseline.comment: US$2692 on average (national)

target.comment: 5000 households’ incomes increase by 10% on average by project end through increased land productivity

actual.comment: 0 household with increase in income

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Total amount of CO2 equivalent greenhouse gas emission avoided, and sequestered at the target sites due to effective application of SLM good practices

baseline.comment: Total national emissions from AFOLU 135.37, Gg CO2-e (2007).

target.comment: Avoided emission of 689333 CO2-eq for 4 years and sequestration of store additionally 10,755 tCO2eq.

actual.comment: No Emission at this stage

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Communities and farmers are able to undertake and benefit from integrated land and water management on their traditionally owned lands.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1.       Number of certified organic farmers/farms

baseline.comment: 606 certified currently exist; 345 in Savaii & 261 in Upolu

target.comment: A 30% increase in number of households engaged in organic farming or more ecological farming

actual.comment: No household/No farmer as of yet getting organic certification

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2.       Increased density and diversity of native tree species in cyclone damaged landscapes around Apia covering 3314 ha

baseline.comment: With recent damage by TC Evans, baseline will be determined when project start.

target.comment: At least 50% increase forest cover in a landscape

actual.comment: Once the recruitment of the GIS specialist is finalized and on-board the project, the baseline will be determined and established.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3.       Area of natural forests, riverine areas and wetlands under protection and management in the production landscape under community landuse plans (forest and tree cover maintenance; maintenance of wetlands; no net increase of agricultural land under mono cropping)

target.comment: By the end of the project, at least 55000 ha will be under integrated landscape management outside KBAs

actual.comment:
- 0 ha under integrated landscape management outside KBAs.
- Meantime initial consultation and discussion within the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment as part of project planning to safeguard a critical Apia Watershed Basin to come under the State forest and watershed protection promoting integrated landscape management. This integrated landscape management inclusive of all villages within the Apia Watershed Basin would be part of the community commitment to forest protection and conservation that will be featured in their Sustainable Village Development Plan.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 4.       Number of farmer households adopting at least one or more soil / water management and conservation practices on agricultural lands

baseline.comment: There are 10790 households in the target area of the project, but with limited soil and water conservation activities

target.comment: At least 5000 households will be adopting soil management and conservation practices in their land by the end of the project covering at least 18000 ha

actual.comment: 0 household

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: 5.       Increased water quality as a consequence of enhanced watershed management and water source protection

baseline.comment: Water quality at sampled sites (3 major sites) shows confirmed incidences of E.coli presence exceeding national standards

target.comment: At least 50% of the project sites report on increased water quality by the end of the project – including E. coli levels within national standards; and additional parameters of nutrient loads (such as nitrogen) are also within acceptable international standards

actual.comment:
- 0% of water quality improvement
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: 6.       Per cent of Livestock relocated to optimal grazing areas away from critical riparian areas

baseline.comment: Estimated 30000 livestock in target areas, covering 5000 ha

target.comment: At least 50% relocated, covering 2500 ha

actual.comment:
- 0% relocation with no ha
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: 7.       Number of integrated participatory village level SLM plans

baseline.comment: No village plans incorporating SLM

target.comment: At least 50 villages have developed plans integrating SLM with the participation of 15000 community member including men, women and young

actual.comment:
- No village with Integrating SLM Plan
- Progress to date including workshop preparation with key stakeholders eg. Ministry of Women, Social Development in preparation for review of Community/Village Development Plan to ensure integration of SLM.
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: 8.       Number of community members that report on increased knowledge and capacity on SLM

baseline.comment: No reports on knowledge on SLM

target.comment: At least 40% of the communities are able to report on increased knowledge on SLM through access to national SLM system, audio-video materials and trainings

actual.comment:
- No report at this stage on knowledge of SLM
- Progress to date include recruitment process of an expert in designing Sustainable Agriculture and SLM awareness materials to assist with community training on SLM/Agriculture best practices.
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Strengthened national enabling environment to promote integrated landscape management through local households and communities.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 9.       Soil management and conservation manual targeting local communities in local language

baseline.comment: No soil management and conservation manual

target.comment: By the end of year 1 a Soil management and conservation manual developed including SLM practices for agriculture, forestry and water resources management

actual.comment: Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 10.       Number of national policies and plans that support for inter-sectoral and partnership approach to promote community based SLM

baseline.comment: A number of policies and plans to support SLM (see section 1.5 of the project document) but inter-sectoral approach is weak

target.comment:
Land Resource management legislation developed and national landuse policy updated
Agriculture Sector Plan 2011-2016 strengthen to mainstream SLM approaches and management practices
policies on mining (including sand mining) strengthened or developed
formal guidelines for sustainable land management under village development plans under PUMA Act developed

actual.comment:
- No policy review to date
- Progress to date include preparation works with the Ministry of MNRE through the Land Management Division for policy review of existing land resource management policy and legislation to ensure SLM is incorporated and strengthened across all levels eg. policy, operation and implementation, monitoring
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 11.      Increased capacities for INRM as measured by an increase in the score of the GEF LD Tracking Tool Enhanced cross-sector enabling environment for integrated landscape management

actual.comment:
- 0
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 12.       Coordination mechanism in place to ensure multi-sector approach to SLM in line with National Environment management Strategy

baseline.comment: No coordination mechanisms for SLM

target.comment: By the end of the project a formal institutional coordination mechanism has been established including all relevant ministries to ensure integration of SLM in all sectors to manage multiuse landscapes through combined efforts, shared technical resources

actual.comment:
- No coordination mechanism in place
- Progress to date include the drafting of the Institutional Coordinated Mechanism for the Project to ensure multi-sectoral approach to SLM.
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: 13.       Increased involvement of private sector, civil society and others in promoting SLM in partnership with the government.

baseline.comment: SFA and WIBDI – NGOs assisting communities with projects that are SLM compatible.

target.comment: By Year 4, the number of NGOs and private partners in SLM is increased by 200%.

actual.comment:
- NGOs and CSOs such as Samoa Farmer Association (SFA), Women in Business (WIB) and Matua-le-oo (METI), Samoa Conservation Society (CSO) and SUNGO have been consulted and have shown interest with partnership to include SLM into their work. Some of these NGO for instance WIB and METI has already worked with the community through training of farmers into some sort of SLM approach.
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to the actual implementation of this component in the 4th Quarter 2015 once training materials have been finalized.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: 14.       National SLM information system in line with information system for national Environment Management Strategy

baseline.comment: No SLM information system

target.comment: By Year 4 an SLM information System will be established and managed by MNRE

actual.comment:
- No SLM Information system established yet
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: 15.       Number of government staff who have completed new training of trainers short term courses provided by USP on SLM, tailored for Samoa and including carbon accounting from LULUCF

baseline.comment: No SLM training currently available at USP for government staff

target.comment: By the end of the project, at least 100 staff from MNRE, MAF, MWCSC have completed the SLM training at USP

actual.comment:
- 0 staff training on SLM
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: 16.       Number of long term courses institutionalized in USP to degree students on SLM

baseline.comment: No SLM courses available at University for undergraduate students

target.comment: By the end of the project, at least 1 SLM long term course has been institutionalized at USP

actual.comment:
- No SLM course designed at USP as of yet
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

result.title: Objective
result.description: Increase the resilience of the tourism sector of Samoa through mainstreaming climate risks into tourism-related policy processes which guide the implementation of adaptation actions by tourism operators and tourism reliant communities.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Capacity perception index of STA disaggregated by gender; AMAT 2.2.2)
(1=no capacity built
2=initial awareness raised
3=substantial training in practical application
4=knowledge effectively transferred
5=ability to apply or disseminate knowledge demonstrated)

baseline.comment: Capacity of STA is currently rated at 2-3.

target.comment: By the end of the project the capacity is 4-5.

actual.comment: At the end of this review period, the rated capacity of the STA has progressed to 3 – 4. This is due to the involvement of staff in the project workshops carried out during the reported period. The Participatory Three (3) Dimensional Model workshops conducted during the formulation of the TDA Management Plans brought STA staff to learn and participate in this key part of the project.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: % of tourism operators who invest and implement sustainable adaptation measures to enhance their resilience.

baseline.comment: Tourism operators are not investing in sustainable adaptation measures, but instead in quick and unsustainable measures to cope with climate risks

target.comment: At least 75% of all tourism operators in the 6 targeted TDAs have invested and implemented sustainable adaptation measures

actual.comment:
An approximate of 30% of operators in the TDAs are investing in sustainable adaptation measures. Operators have learned of the importance of replanting initiatives. Manase operators for instance had not opted for a rock seawall for protection through gained knowledge that this will speed up erosion resulting in total loss of their beach. Villages in the TDAs have also reported that sand-mining has been banned for commercial use and monitored by the village council and are supported by some of the village bylaws for the villages who have completed these.
Furthermore, the beach fale operator at Satuiatua which is one of the TDAs on Savaii has been advocating in their village to stop the removal of the beach rocks along the shore.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Climate change adaptation mainstreamed into tourism-related policy instruments and public-private partnerships

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: # of Management Plans developed and operationalized

baseline.comment: Climate resilient management plans are currently not in place

target.comment: By the end of the project, at least 6 climate resilient management plans have been developed and operationalized per TDA, involving at least 20 villages in total.

actual.comment: The project has received 6 draft TDA Management Plans from the Water Technology company. The project is currently undertaking its first review.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: % of tourism operators in targeted TDAs apply new guidelines for climate resilient actions

baseline.comment: No guidelines exist for effective no-regrets adaptation measures to increase resilience of tourism operators and there is a history of little application of guidelines is commonly low

target.comment: By the end of the project, at least 75% of the targeted tourism operators apply the issued guidelines

actual.comment: The Guidelines are currently being drafted and hope foreseen to be finalized once received by mid July 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: # of tourism operators that gain access to financial products for climate resilient actions

baseline.comment: Tourism operators do not access financial products for climate resilient actions

target.comment: By the end of the project, at least 15 operators have successfully gained access to financial products for climate resilient actions

actual.comment: At the moment, the Small Grants Scheme Guidelines are being drafted and finalised to roll out the funds for climate resilient activities. Informal agreement and discussions took place with the PSSF (Private Sector Support Facility) for channelling funds in respect of environmental safeguards. A Small Grant facilitator will be hired by the project to streamline the process of channelling grants and implementation of climate resilient actions. Operators are eagerly awaiting the opportunity through the Small Grants component of the project to assist with the climate resilient projects.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Increased adaptive capacity to climate change and disaster risks of tourism-reliant communites

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number and type of risk reduction activities introduced in tourism reliant communities (AMAT 2.3.1.1)

baseline.comment: No Operators with Business plans which incorporate climate smart risk assessment & planning

target.comment: At least five risk reduction activities have been introduced across the 9 villages in the 6 TDAs

actual.comment: At the moment, the Manase Detailed Design for Beach Replenishment and control for coastal protection is currently underway which will benefit the whole village of Manase. Beach fale operators at Saleapaga in south east Upolu have also with the assistance of other line projects completed an evacuation route that will benefit the whole village of Saleapaga.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: % of women and men in tourism reliant communities trained in climate risk reduction

baseline.comment: Initial awareness raising activities have taken place in the project area under the PPG phase, but no systematic training has been provided on

target.comment: By the end of the project at least 50% of the women and 50% of the men of the targeted communities has been trained in climate risk reduction

actual.comment: An integrated training program for the TDAs targeted has been recommended under the TDA Management Plans to be part of the wider Samoa Tourism Support Programme (STSP). The CLEWS component of this project will also hold workshops and trainings for the TDAs. Introductory information was provided through the Tourism Cyclone Recovery Programme (TCRP) Financial Risk Management assessment on geo hazards and climate futures. Women and men have been consistently equally present at the workshops conducted. The P3D model workshops, held in each TDA to inform the Management plans, have also served to train communities on the most threatening climate risks with specific reference to each particular geographical context.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: % of targeted tourism reliant communities that have adopted climate resilient livelihoods

baseline.comment: Apart from some ad-hoc measures individuals are taking, none of the targeted communities have climate resilient livelihoods

target.comment: By the end of the project at least 80% of the targeted communities have adopted climate resilient livelihoods

actual.comment: Targeted TDAs are adopting climate resilient livelihoods and are starting with relocation of some of the key infrastructures in the safe zones such as the ones on the south eastern side of Upolu (Saleapaga and Lalomanu), as a result of information received through the project. Some of the operators at Manase have started to move some of their assets further away from the beach. Plantation tours, visit to nearby attractions including cultural and natural sites such as the Mt Matavanu crater, caves, pools and village walks have also been considered as key activities for tourists to complement the beach experience.

iati-activity.title: Ridge to Reef in Niue (PPG)
iati-activity.description: This project will enhance the Niue’s capacities to effectively create and manage its protected areas, focusing on the expansion of its Protected Areas estate on land and on its marine areas. (PPG)

iati-activity.title: Ridge to Reef
iati-activity.description: This is the preparatory phase of the full-size project of Ridge to Reef in Niue. (Estimate Budget is US$4,194,862)
